an4.16:4.1: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of subtlety.
an4.16:4.3: A mendicant has ultimate subtlety of form.
an4.16:4.4: They don’t see any other subtlety of form that’s better or superior than that,
an4.16:4.5: nor do they aim for it.
an4.16:4.6: A mendicant has ultimate subtlety of feeling.
an4.16:4.7: They don’t see any other subtlety of feeling that’s better or superior than that,
an4.16:4.8: nor do they aim for it.
an4.16:4.9: A mendicant has ultimate subtlety of perception.
an4.16:4.10: They don’t see any other subtlety of perception that’s better or superior than that,
an4.16:4.11: nor do they aim for it.
an4.16:4.12: A mendicant has ultimate subtlety of choices.
an4.16:4.13: They don’t see any other subtlety of choices that’s better or superior than that,
an4.16:4.14: nor do they aim for it.
an4.16:6.2: peaceful, in love with the state of peace.
an4.16:6.4: having defeated Māra and his mount.”
